{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3349552,"name":"avi","username":"mar56vel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-01T20:49:19.874Z","cooked":"

my team really wants to buy a CNC router next year, and we’re having some difficulties finding one. our budget is around 5k (we’re thinking of buying a second hand one so we can get a more expensive model for cheaper) sizewise, we want something around 90 x 60 cm.
if anyone knows what are the best models - and the difference between them , or knows someone who explain this already and can point me to them i would really appreciate it.
also, if someone’s team here had a (positive or negative) experience with a cerite model and can tell me that would be great.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-04-02T06:59:57.536Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":313,"reads":451,"readers_count":450,"score":1655.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460953,"topic_slug":"help-with-buying-a-cnc-router","display_username":"avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60010,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-buying-a-cnc-router/460953/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3349614,"name":"Cory","username":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-01T21:57:16.204Z","cooked":"

Lots of discussion of routers on here. Recommend you search some and you’ll find great info.

“not too expensive” is too vague. What specifically are you hoping to spend?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-04-01T21:57:16.204Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":434,"readers_count":433,"score":106.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460953,"topic_slug":"help-with-buying-a-cnc-router","display_username":"Cory","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":1037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-buying-a-cnc-router/460953/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3349615,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-01T22:03:35.971Z","cooked":"

Omio X8-2200 USB is the way to go if you’re on a medium budget, but they tend to wear down after a few years, especially the spindles. I’ve heard great things about the Shopsabre brand, but they are around $10-15k for the Shopsabre 23 (which is a little bigger than the Omio).

We have a ShopSabre 23 and love it. Reliable and easy to use/program. Been through a few shop moves and a flood (unfortunately) and survived. Great machine.

Highly recommend the Carbide 3D routers if you are looking for large work area pretty cheap. Also a fan of Millright CNC products. If you could be a little more specific about what you are looking for, I would love to share more!

yea i was a bit vague, we have a budget of 5k- and we’re looking for one with a Automatic tool changer

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-04-02T05:25:35.322Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":281,"readers_count":280,"score":66.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460953,"topic_slug":"help-with-buying-a-cnc-router","display_username":"avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":1037,"username":"Cory","name":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60010,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-buying-a-cnc-router/460953/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3349938,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-02T05:30:26.813Z","cooked":"

I took a quick look at Omio X8, which is a pretty standard FRC-level router. $4K, no automatic tool changer, from WCP. You might need more budget.

For most routers, I’d probably say an automatic tool changer is the least of your concerns; you’d probably want a cooling system first if the machine doesn’t come with one. If you were talking a CNC mill then the tool changer is more attractive of an option.

My team bough the X-carve from inventables this year and we are really pleased with it, we have cut 1/4" lexan and aluminum, its a learning curve as with everything but super usefull. They have several models, we got the cheaper one and are happy with it but I would have prefered one of the pro models if we had the budget.

You can find the specs here: X-Carve Vs. X-Carve Pro – Inventables, Inc.
We have used the program that comes with the machine called Easel and its pretty simple to use, I think the machine comes with a 1 year license but you can get a 3 year license for $600.

osofdez:

My team bough the X-carve from inventables this year and we are really pleased with it, we have cut 1/4" lexan and aluminum, its a learning curve as with everything but super usefull.

How fast are you removing material with the X-carve? My experience with X-carve and Shapeoko is that they advertise very large work areas but cut much slower than an Omio, often by a factor of five or more.

I have not seen a CNC Router with tool changer in the price range you are looking at. I’d recommend that you take a look at Sain Smart CNC machines. They are on the cheaper end but still have great quality. Only thing is that you will probably want to put a more powerful spindle on it, but it comes with the mounting bracket for that.

9072 has the Shapeoko 5 Pro CNC Router - Carbide 3D and have had a great time cutting wood of varied thickness and tons of 1/4 in polycarb. There was an issue with the control unit that carbide helped diagnose and sent a replace unit for under warranty. Right now, the compact router is installed since there was a delay at the start of the season with the spindle. But the spindle on paper should be able to cut faster and be pushed harder especially when dialing in setting for aluminum. For now, all the settings have been stock, besides increasing depth per pass. (Shout out to 4795 - Eastbots for helping us get started quick! Went from packaged boxes to cutting polycarb in less than 24hrs)

When it comes to changing tools with the compact router it has been fairly painless, but the tools that come with the router are not strong enough and broke after a few swaps. After switching to standard wrenches there have been no issues.

Help with buying a CNC router Technical
How fast are you removing material with the X-carve? My experience with X-carve and Shapeoko is that they advertise very large work areas but cut much slower than an Omio, often by a factor of five or more.

@asid61 I’m curious about the settings that you are using, even with the stock settings the cutting speed has been good, and the large bed size has allowed to get a lot of parts started at once.

Edit: The Shapeoko 5 Pro comes with a BitSetter which makes swapping the bit easier as well since it can measure it after replacement.

We purchased a used Shopbot Desktop MAX, and we’ve been very happy with it. 36x24 work area is plenty large enough for anything we need to make in FRC. We’ve attached a WCP boxtube fixture to the bed, meaning we can quickly and reliably route boxtube pieces, as well as sheet polycarb, aluminum, and wood. Tooling is cheap, and since we work in Inventor, we can easily do our CAM and send to the machine without changing environments. We paid exactly $5000 for the machine, and it came with the preivous owner’s rolling cart and a few endmills. We’ve picked up a few hundred dollars in additional collets and tooling, and we’re so happy with it that we’re looking at grabbing another.

Edit: I see above you were asking about feeds/speeds. This will depend as much on your tooling as it does on your machine, but we’ve had great luck using the default tool libraries built in to Fusion and Inventor. Pick the material, pick a tool from the library that matches your specs, and go - it usually just works.

I love ATCs, but you will not get a new CNC router with ATC for less than $5k.

And for FRC you really don’t need an ATC. 4mm endmills can cut most of the features need for an FRC team without requiring tool changes. As others have mentioned the Omio X8 is probably the best bang for buck machine you can buy today.

If you absolutely must have an ATC look into https://rapidchangeatc.com/. I do not have any personal experience with this product but it seems like the best bet for adding an ATC to a low cost router like the Omio.

Which size Shapeoko did you get?

And, you mentioned wanting to cut aluminum on the Shapeoko. Do you have a sheet metal brake? I’m asking because one of the great things about places like SendCutSend is that they both cut AND bend pieces – a lot of our aluminum has been for sheet-metal supports that we rivet onto our bellypan and chassis. If we cut the aluminum ourselves, then we’re still stuck on the bending part.
